questions.text: A 26yr old G3A1P1 with 38 weeks of gestation presents with a history of pain abdomen, backache, contractions, and show. She has no comorbidities. Her first and second trimester USG is normal. On examination, P-90/min, saturation normal, afebrile, RR-14/min, BP-130/80mmHg, pallor present. Abdominal examination shows fundus just below xiphisternum, vertical lie, cephalic presentation, head engaged, FHR-140/min, contractions-5/10mins. PV examination shows cervix soft, effaced, 4cm dilated, 2cm long, head at station 0, membranes intact. NST is normal. She delivered a 3.2kg baby vaginally but had postpartum hemorrhage due to an Atonic uterus. The correct sequence of management of such cases is- Angiographic arterial embolization Massage the uterus and start oxytocin B lynch compression 15methyl PGF2 250mcg im Balloon tamponade or bimanual compression Select the correct answer from the code below:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

2,4,5,3,1 The given clinical case scenario is that of management of the atonic uterus. The correct sequence of management according to the given statements in question is: Massage the uterus and start oxytocin 15methyl PGF2 250mcg im Balloon tamponade or bimanual compression . B lynch compression Angiographic arterial embolization

Causes of PPH Atonic PPH (Tone) It is the most common cause of primary PPH accounting for 90% of cases. The bleeding occurs as the blood vessels are not obliterated by contraction and retraction of uterine muscle fibres Traumatic PPH (Trauma) Genital tract injuries like: Lacerations of the cervix, vagina and perineum; Colporrhexis and Rupture uterus Coagulopathy (Thrombin) Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC) and hypofibrinogenemia are rare causes of PPH Other causes (Tissue) Retained products of conception Remember: 4T's

Extraedge:

Management algorithm for PPH (HEMOSTASIS) Proposed by Chandraharan and Arulkumaran H Ask for help and hands on uterus E Establish aetiology, ensure ABC, ensure availability of blood and ecobolics (drugs that contract the uterus) M Massage of uterus O Oxytocin infusion/Prostaglandins S Shift to theatre - aortic pressure or antishock garment T Tamponade balloon/ uterine packing (consider tranexemic acid 1 gm) A Apply compression suture S Systemic pelvic devascularization - uterine/internal iliac artery I Interventional radiology S Subtotal/total hysterectomy

questions.text: A 28-Year-old G3P2L1 with 39 weeks of gestation presents with pain abdomen, contractions, backache, and show. She is a case of twin gestation with severe anemia treated one week ago with blood transfusion with post-transfusion Hb - 6g/dL. Her first and second trimester USG is normal. She had two vaginal deliveries, one 3yrs ago, delivered a term stillborn, and another 2yrs ago, a normal baby weighing 3kg. On examination, P-80/min, BP-130/84mmHg, afebrile, saturation normal, RR-15/min, pallor seen, B/L pedal edema upto ankle seen. Abdominal examination shows fundus just below xiphisternum, multiple fetal parts felt, FHR1-136/min, FHR2- 140/min, abdominal contractions- 5/10mins. PV examination shows cervix soft, effaced, 5cm dilated, 2cm long, head of the first twin at station +1, membranes absent. She delivered both twins vaginally. Uncontrollable bleeding occurred during the third stage of labor, almost > 1200ml. The atonic uterus was noticed. The cause of this condition, in this case, could be -
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Both a and b The clinical scenario is multipara with twin gestation with anemia developing Atonic uterus leading to postpartum hemorrhage . Although uterine fibroid is a cause of the Atonic uterus, the presence of uterine fibroid is not mentioned in the given clinical history. Hence it is not the answer. Atonic uterus (80 Percent): Atonicity of the uterus is the commonest cause of postpartum hemorrhage. The following are the conditions that often interfere with the retraction of the uterus and the placental site in particular. Grand multipara —Inadequate retraction and frequent adherent placenta contribute to it. Associated anemia may also probably play a role. Over distension of the uterus as in multiple pregnancies, hydramnios, and big babies ( > 4 kg). Imperfect retraction and a large placental site are responsible for excessive bleeding. Malnutrition and anemia ( < 9.0 g/dL) —Even a slight amount of blood loss may develop clinical manifestations of postpartum hemorrhage. Antepartum hemorrhage (Both placenta previa and abruption): Prolonged labor ( > 12 hours): Poor retraction, infection (amnionitis), and dehydration are essential factors (Tone). Anesthesia: Depth of anesthesia and the anesthetic agents (ether, halothane) may cause atonicity. Initiation or augmentation of delivery by oxytocin: Post-delivery uterine atonicity is likely unless the oxytocin is continued for at least one hour following delivery. Malformation of the uterus : Implantation of the placenta in the uterine septum of a septate uterus or the corneal region of a bicornuate uterus may cause excessive bleeding. Uterine fibroid causes imperfect retraction mechanically. The mismanaged third stage of labor : This includes—(a) Too rapid delivery of the baby, preventing the uterine wall from adapting to the diminishing contents, (b) Premature attempt to deliver the placenta before it is separated, (c) Kneading and fiddling the uterus, (d) Pulling the cord. All these produce irregular uterine contractions leading to partial separation of the placenta and hemorrhage, (e) Manual separation of the placenta increases blood loss during cesarean delivery. Placenta : Morbidly adherent (accreta, percreta), wholly or partially separated and retained cause PPH. Precipitate labor : The placenta is separated following the baby's birth in rapid delivery. Bleeding continues before the onset of uterine retraction. Bleeding may be due to genital tract trauma also. Other causes of atonic hemorrhage are Obesity (BMI > 35), • Previous PPH • Age ( > 40 yrs), t Drugs: Use of tocolytic drugs (ritodrine), MgSO4, Nifedipine.

Highyeild:

The average blood loss following vaginal delivery, cesarean delivery, and cesarean hysterectomy is 500 mL, 1000 mL, and 1500 mL, respectively. Depending upon the amount of blood loss, PPH can be Minor (< 1L), Major (> 1L), or Severe (>2L).

Management algorithm for PPH (HEMOSTASIS) Proposed by Chandraharan and Arulkumaran H Ask for help and hands on uterus E Establish aetiology, ensure ABC, ensure availability of blood and ecobolics (drugs that contract the uterus) M Massage of uterus O Oxytocin infusion/Prostaglandins S Shift to theatre - aortic pressure or antishock garment T Tamponade balloon/ uterine packing (consider tranexemic acid 1 gm) A Apply compression suture S Systemic pelvic devascularization - uterine/internal iliac artery I Interventional radiology S Subtotal/total hysterectomy

questions.text: A 28-Year-old woman, postpartum day 10, presents with a history of bleeding PV, and generalized weakness. She had a standard vaginal delivery. The child is normal, and she is breastfeeding. The discharge had reduced two days ago but suddenly increased since 1day. On examination, P-98/min, BP-110/70mmHg, RR-20/min, pallor present, saturation normal, temperature-100F. No abdominal tenderness. PV examination shows no lesions or trauma. USG was advised. The most common cause for such secondary hemorrhage could be -

options.label: A
options.text: Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes

options.label: B
options.text: Infection and separation of the slough

questions.correct_answer: A. Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes The given clinical scenario is secondary postpartum hemorrhage . The most common cause is Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes. Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes Retained bits of cotyledon or membranes (most common)

questions.text: A 30-Year-old G3P2 woman with a history of hypertension presents to the birthing floor in labor. Following prolonged labor and delivery with no fetal complications, she bleeds vaginally but remains afebrile. Her uterus is soft, boggy, and enlarged on a bimanual examination. There are no visible lacerations. Uterine massage decreases the bleeding, and oxytocin is only mildly effective. Which of the following is the next best step in mgt?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

PGF2Alpha This is a case of Atonic PPH as the patient has presented with vaginal bleeding immediately after delivery, and the uterus is not palpable per abdominally, i.e., it has lost its tone. In Atonic PPH, the first step in management should be uterotonic agents like oxytocin or methyl ergometrine. If either does not control bleeding, straightaway PGF2a carboprost should be used.

questions.text: A 30-Year-oldprimigravida with 38 weeks of gestation was delivered in the ambulance while being shifted to the hospital. She has no history of comorbidities. A pediatrician examined the neonate, and it was normal. On examination, P-90/min, Bp-110/70mmHg, RR-20/min, saturation-95 Percent, pallor present, afebrile. Placenta is expelled, but there is still bleeding. There is no visible trauma; the uterus is atonic. She was started on oxytocin and was administered Methergine followed by misoprostol. The bleeding did not stop. Hence the next, as shown in the image, was done. True statements about this procedure are all except?

options.label: A
options.text: It stimulates uterine contraction and acts as direct hemostatic pressure to uterine sinuses

options.label: C
options.text: It is inflated with normal saline - 200-500ml

questions.correct_answer: B. It does not avoid hysterectomy
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It does not avoid hysterectomy The given clinical scenario points towards postpartum hemorrhage due to an Atonic uterus . The given image is that of a balloon tamponade done to control postpartum bleeding. Balloon tamponade : Tamponade using various types of hydrostatic balloon catheters has mostly replaced uterine packing. It is successful in atonic PPH. This can avoid hysterectomy in 78 Percent of cases. It is considered the first-line surgical intervention for most women with atonic PPH.

Highyeild:

Mechanical methods : When medical procedures fail to control PPH, the following mechanical methods are adopted: Bimanual compression Uterine packing under anesthesia Balloon tamponade with a song-taken tube inserted into the uterus. } To create a tamponade effect and compress the placental bed Shivkars pack, i.e., a condom inflated with saline and tied to a nasogastric tube, can also be used as a tamponade.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Intrauterine plugging stimulates uterine contraction and exerts direct hemostatic pressure (tamponade effect) on the open uterine sinuses. Option: C. and D. Foley catheter, Bakri balloon, Condom catheter, or Sengstaken-Blakemore tube is inserted into the uterine cavity, and the balloon is inflated with normal saline (200–500 mL). It is kept for 4–6 hours.

questions.text: A 30-Year-oldprimigravida with 39 weeks of gestation had normal vaginal delivery 3 hours ago at a PHC and has been referred for treatment of postpartum hemorrhage. The baby weighs 3kg and is normal. She was administered oxytocin and Methergine, but the bleeding didn't subside, and she was referred. On examination, P-80/min, BP-120/82mmHg, afebrile, saturation normal, RR-14/min, pallor present. The abdomen has no tenderness. PV examination shows no visible injuries. Balloon tamponade and bimanual compression were tried, but the bleeding didn't stop. Suturing was done as shown below to control the bleeding. It is known as?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

B - Lynch suture The clinical scenario is postpartum hemorrhage due to the Atonic uterus. The image shows B- Lynch compression sutures. B-Lynch compression suture (1997) and multiple square sutures: These surgical methods work by tamponade (like bimanual compression) of the uterus. The success rate is about 80 percent, and it can avoid hysterectomy.

Highyeild:

Surgical methods to control PPH

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option A and C. are used for the management of cervical incompetence

Extraedge:

Blynch Suture (Brace suture) is an alternative to the vessel ligation technique in the surgical management of PPH. B lynch suture involves vertical brace sutures, which oppose the uterus's anterior and posterior walls, leading to compression of the fundus and the lower uterine segment, thereby controlling the bleeding. The main advantage is that it is effortless to perform and may prevent the need for a hysterectomy. It is commonly performed at cesarean section but can also be done after vaginal delivery.

questions.text: A P1L1 who delivered a male child recently by vaginal delivery cannot lactate her baby as there is no breast milk production. On further history, she says that her delivery was complicated by postpartum hemorrhage. Examination revealed the features of hypothyroidism and cortisol deficiency. Which of the following sentence is not true about this condition?

options.label: D
options.text: May occur following severe postpartum hemorrhage

questions.correct_answer: B. It is called Simmond disease
questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is called Simmond disease The woman in this question has panhypopituitarism following severe PPH. This is called Sheehan syndrome. Simmond disease is the destruction of the anterior lobe of the pituitary gland by any cause like embolic infarction, tumor, syphilis, tuberculosis, metastasis, etc.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Sheehan syndrome is associated with panhypopituitarism. Features are lactational failure, amenorrhoea, cortisol deficiency, hypothyroidism, etc. Option: C. Due to decreased blood supply, the pituitary gland is necrosed and shrunken. MRI shows empty sella turcica. Option: D. Sheehan syndrome occurs after severe postpartum hemorrhage.

questions.text: All of the following are used to manage PPH except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

NOVO-7 NOVO T is activated factor 7. Its role is well-established in hemophilia. Activated factor VII (NOVOT) binds with tissue factors to augment the intrinsic clotting pathway by activating factors IX and X. However, its role in obstetrical hemorrhage is uncertain, and it is not used in these cases due to the risk of thromboembolic events like MI.

questions.text: The following statements are related to obstetric inversion:

options.label: A
options.text: It is usually insidious in onset

options.label: D
options.text: In the majority; it is spontaneous in nature

questions.explanation:
Solution:

It is usually acute Uterine inversion is a condition in which the uterus turns inside-out. It is a rare cause of postpartum collapse, but collapse occurs suddenly after labor. Mostly uterine inversion is complete, i.e., third degree

Highyeild:

Aetiology Mismanagement of the third stage (M/C cause) - Attempting to deliver a placenta by separating (Crede's method). Spontaneous inversion can occur with an atonic uterus (in 40% of cases). Placenta accreta is a rare cause.
